thread.title: Quorn owner smashes £200m turnover mark as firm focuses on marketing

author: Jonathon Manning
title: Quorn owner smashes £200m turnover mark as firm focuses on marketing
text:
Quorn owner smashes £200m turnover mark as firm focuses on marketing Marlow Foods owns vegetarian food brands Quorn and Cauldron Foods Share Get business updates directly to your inbox + Subscribe Thank you for subscribing! Could not subscribe, try again later Invalid Email
The owner of vegetarian food company Quorn has added almost £30m to its turnover after upping its marketing activity.
Stokesley’s Marlow Foods - which owns the Quorn and Cauldron Foods brands - saw its turnover jump 16.2% from £176.1m to £204.6m for the year ending December 2017.
The company said the huge increase in its revenues was largely due to it investing in marketing. The company is best known for its TV ad campaigns featuring double Olympic gold medal winner Mo Farah.
In Marlow’s accounts, chief financial officer James Harvey said: “The group delivered a strong performance with turnover at £204.6m. Sales growth was 16.2%.
“Sales in the UK continued to perform well with growth being driven through increased investment in consumer and customer marketing activities. Sales in overseas markets were also strong especially in the USA, Nordics, Australia and Germany.”
The UK continues to be Marlow Foods’ biggest market, making up three quarters of the firm’s revenue. UK sales grew from £136.7m to £152.4m during the year. Overseas sales continued to increase with European sales jumping 33% to £31.9m, while revenue from the rest of the world increased from £15.3m to £20.4m. While the company continued to grow overseas, it emphasised that it would not halt its investment plans due to Brexit.
Mr Harvey said: “The uncertainty of Brexit negotiations makes it difficult to assess the future impact over future trade in Europe, however, we continue to review the situation and we do not plan to limit out planned investment to grow our international business.”
Quorn recently revealed it was creating hundreds of jobs in Teesside over the next five years as part of plans to create a new £7m headquarters in Stokesley. The develop is being carried out to create a “high tech powerhouse” for the global brand in the North East. However, Mr Harvey added that the group had suffered increased costs due to “exposure to foreign currencies” and “commodity price fluctuation”.
Despite the increased costs the group’s operating profit increased by 27% to £31.9m. Profit after tax also grew to £20.4m.
Marlow Foods also increased its headcount from 657 members of staff to 703 in 2017. More jobs have been added after the accounts period, with staff numbers now standing at around 750. Like us on Facebook
